Literature Review: Adjective ordering across languages has been a subject of intense linguistic research, revealing intriguing patterns that suggest a universal cognitive framework underlying language structure. This literature review synthesizes findings from various studies to explore the nature of adjective ordering preferences, their cross-linguistic regularities, and the theoretical explanations proposed to account for these phenomena. The consistent ordering preferences observed across diverse languages, from English to Mandarin to Hebrew, underscore the potential universality of these patterns. Research by Cinque (1994) and Sproat and Shih (1991) has been pivotal in documenting these preferences, highlighting a hierarchy that adjectives tend to follow when modifying a noun. This hierarchy is not arbitrary but seems to be influenced by semantic factors, such as the inherent properties of the adjectives and their relationship to the noun they modify. For instance, adjectives denoting size typically precede those indicating color in English, a pattern that has been observed in other languages as well. The work of Scott (2002) further supports this, demonstrating that the semantic closeness of an adjective to the noun it modifies plays a crucial role in determining its position in the sequence. Cross-linguistic studies, such as those conducted by Dryer (1992) and Hawkins (1983), have expanded our understanding by comparing adjective ordering across a wide range of languages, revealing both universal tendencies and language-specific variations. These studies suggest that while there is a strong universal component to adjective ordering, individual languages may exhibit unique patterns based on their syntactic and morphological structures. Theoretical explanations for these ordering preferences have varied, with some researchers attributing them to cognitive processing constraints. For example, the principle of 'end-weight' proposed by Quirk et al. (1985) suggests that longer or more complex adjectives tend to be placed closer to the noun to facilitate processing. Similarly, the 'iconicity' hypothesis, as discussed by Haiman (1983), posits that the order of adjectives reflects the conceptual closeness of their meanings to the noun. More recent work by Alexiadou et al. (2007) has explored the syntactic underpinnings of adjective ordering, arguing that the hierarchical structure of the noun phrase plays a significant role in determining adjective position. This perspective aligns with the findings of Laenzlinger (2005), who emphasizes the importance of syntactic features in shaping adjective order across languages. Despite the progress made in understanding adjective ordering preferences, questions remain about the extent of their universality and the factors that influence language-specific deviations. Future research, particularly cross-linguistic studies that incorporate a broader range of languages and consider both syntactic and semantic factors, will be crucial in addressing these questions. The study of adjective ordering not only sheds light on the cognitive processes underlying language production and comprehension but also contributes to our broader understanding of linguistic universals and the diversity of human language.
